name: Angola
takeaway: In 2023, Angola and the PRC marked 40 years of the establishment of diplomatic relations. This resulted in an increase in activities and exchanges, particularly at the political level. The celebration has also been reflected in the growth of pro-PRC narratives across sectors of Angolan society, from the media, to academia, and beyond.

Trade is at the core of China-Angola relations, with China being the main importer of Angolan crude oil. China is also a major creditor to Angola. Angola is China's second-largest trading partner in Africa (including all types of goods and services).

China and Angola have a strong partnership in military and defense, which draws on historical connections. Not only is China a supplier of arms to Angola, but the PLA and the Angola Armed Forces have set up a joint-venture for possible collaboration in the defense sector.

Despite the many aspects of Angola-China relations, particularly at government to government level, public opinion towards China in Angola (while not negative) is amongst the least positive in Africa.
description-1: In 2023, Angola had a GDP per capita of US$2,310 and a total population of 36.19 million people.
description-2: Angola established full diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1983. Angola was ranked 104th in Reporters Without Borders‘ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Not Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 28/100.
